stem: The nurse is preparing to provide education to a client who does not speak the same language as the nurse. For each available resource, select whether it is considered a Standard/Safe Communication Method or a Non-Standard/Unsafe Communication Method.

rows.text: Using the client's bilingual 12-year-old child to translate discharge instructions.
Utilizing a hospital-provided video-remote interpretation (VRI) service with a certified medical interpreter.
Typing clinical instructions into a free online 'translation' app on a personal smartphone.
Using a bilingual staff member who has been specifically vetted and 'certified' as a medical translator for the unit.

rationale.correct: Language access is a legal right under Title VI. (r2 & r4) Certified resources ensure medical terminology is accurately preserved and that patient-nurse boundaries are maintained. (r1) Family members (especially children) should *never* be used due to lack of medical knowledge, potential for summarized/omitted info, and boundary violations. (r3) Online apps on personal phones are unvetted, can be inaccurate, and violate HIPAA privacy rules.
rationale.incorrect: Friendliness or family availability does not compensate for the lack of professional medical translation standards.
clinicalPearls: Even if a patient says their family member can translate, the nurse has a duty to provide a certified interpreter for any discussion involving medical decisions or consent.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that you need *informed* consent. If the family member is doing the informing, you can't guarantee it's accurate. Always use the 'professional' answer in NGN.

mnemonic.title: C-O-D-E
mnemonic.expansion: Certified Only, Direct communication, Eliminate children/family, Ethics/Privacy focus.

reviewUnits.heading: Language Access in Healthcare
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must provide 'Limited English Proficiency' (LEP) clients with free access to qualified interpreters. Failing to do so is a form of discrimination and a significant contributor to medical errors.
